Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suskin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suskin, Masowsh, Hedeidsh, Adan. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyon Jeddah bat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Tambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1906.

div.head: THE POWER OF KINGS.
div.p: In the September number of the "Empire Review" Mr. Edward Dicey points out that the Friendrichsof interview illustrates a change in European public opinion, which can hardly have failed to attract the notice of all thoughful students of European politics. Rather more than half a century ago, he says, constitutional government under parliamentary institution was regarded as a sort of panacea for all mundane evils, and as a corollary to this belief monarchies were denounced as effete institutions, only to be tolerated by thinking beings on condition of the monarchs of becoming mere figure-heads of the sovereign people. "What I wish to show is that the belief in the early disappearnce of monarchies, and the reduction of monarch to a subordinance psition, has been absolutely falsified by the events of the last half century. Kings are not only as numerous as ever in this old world of Europe but they are individually more powerful. The politicans of the Bright and Cobden era wer right in supposing that before the nineteeth century had passed away the democracy would have come to the front; they were wrong in assuming that the democracy would necessarily become more and more enamoured of parlimentary institutions. The contrary has proved to be case. In the contarry has proved to be the case. In the old world, at any rate, the ideal of the democracy has shown itself to be One Man Government, and in all monarchila countires the one man, more than not, is the monarch. In England, in Germany, in Belgium, in Holland, in Spain, in Portugal, in Italy, in Austria, in Sweden and Norway, in Roumania, and even in the Balkan States the reigning sovereign holds a personal influence and authority superior to that of his minsiters or his parlimanets. Russia and turkey are both One Man Governements. But no one conversant with either of these two countries can doubt that Sultan, Abdul Hamid, is regarded by his people as the vice-regent of God on earth; and that Czar, Nicolas II., however uncertain his tenture of power may be is still the most effective - or at any rate the least ineffective - personality in the Sclav Empire.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Qurarantine regulations against arrivals from Forbandar Trebeziond have been withdrawn.

div.head: Manieh Ophathaimic Hospital.
div.p: The subscription opend by the modir of Minieh for an ophthamological hospital has so far realised L.E. 1,560.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to October 11 amounted to 1,012, 653 tons, as compared with 812, 530 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: Subscriptions for Persian School.
div.p: The notables of the Persian community held a meeting on Thursday and decided to found a school for the children of poor parents. L.E. 2,000 has already been subscribed for this object.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Sardon's Fedora is billed for this evening at the Alhambra Theatre. Tomorrow's aftternoon there will be a matinee, when La Famille de Pont Biquet will be given, and in the evening the company will stage Tosca.

div.head: Austrian Visit to Renas.
div.p: A correspondent writes from Mariout: -

The Acting Austro-Hungairan Dipmatic Agent payed a visit on the 11th inst. tl the German excavations at old Menas City (Mariout). Military honours were rendered at Bahig station, and he was accompanied by Bimbashi Stagni.

div.head: St. Andrew's Church, Cairo.
div.p: The services in St. Andrew's Church, Cairo, will be resumed for the reason, on Sunday, October 21. The hours of the services will be 10.30 a.m. and 6 p.m. The preacher will be the Rev. Hill P. Reid, of Alexandria. The Rev. James K. McLymound, D.D. of Holburn, Aberdeen, has been appointed by the Committee to conduct the services during the winters.

div.head: The Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 11th October 8 versels, of which 1 was northward and 7 were southward bound, transmited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 2,812, 694. 13, and during that time 107 vessels transited the Canal, 46 being northward and 61 southward bound.

div.head: American Record Breaking.
div.p: A propos of the large numbers of passengers which cross the seas now a days, it is intersting to note that the kaiserin Auguste Vicorira sailed from New York last week with 1,685 passengers, 585 of whom were first class. This total exceeds by ten her record figures of last month and is the greatest number ever sailing on one linear from the port Scores were unable to get accomodation.

div.head: The American Squadron.
div.p: The American Naval Division under Vice Admiral Browson enters the Canal tomorrow morning for the Far East, where Vice Admiral Brownson, as already announced, will assume the chief command. Until Suez, the Division will be technically considered as forming part of the Atlantic Fleet. A large number of the officers went up to Cairo, and returned yesterday to Port Said by the evening train.

div.head: Port Said Library Raided.
div.p: The Anglo American Bookselling Store, in the Rue du Comemrce, Port Said, was raided on Thursday afternoon by Saghcolaghassi Moore, commanding the European caracol, with several of the secret police. The raid resulted in the seizure of 900 obscene photographs, a dozen indecent books, and a considerable quantity of transparent cards. The proprietor of this "library" was known to be the literary purveyor to several of the shps in the main streets.

div.head: Another Armenian Plot.
div.p: The Criminal Court of Stamboul has passed sentence of life impriosment in a fortress upon Vargahach Keulelian, Ohannes Katchounian, Ohannes Arabian, and Mardiros Karabetian. The three frist reside at Varna and Mardiors Karabetian is in Egypt. From letters seized by the authorities it has been ascrtained the above four worthies were conspiriing against the Imperial Government. The setence passed upon them entails the confiscation of their property.

div.head: A Human Brute.
div.p: According to the "Pyramides," at Cairo, on Thursday evening, in the Isamailieh quarter, a native was surprised in the act of committing an outrage on the person of a European girl six years old. Her cries drew the attention of an Englishman, who released the girl, and with the help of a friend, conducted the ruffian to Abdin caracol despite the menaces of a crowd of natives. If the details of this case are as reported, we can only trust that a very servere example will be made of the man.

div.head: Armenian Charities.
div.p: We have received a copy of the statues of the Amrmenian Catholic Charitable Society. Its Committee for the ensuing year Messrs. Missek Massarf, president; Edward Terzi, vice-president; Emile Oghia, secretary; Antoine Bey Manock, treasurer; Baptiste Hekimian, assitant secretary; Jean Dinlik, Garabed O. Haleplian, Edmond Bechara, Antoine Zammarian, Antoire Kalepdjian, Diran-Zepdji and Gregoire, Antoine Kalepdijan, Diran Zepdji and Gregoire Faralian, members. M. Artin Chirianian will act as honorary doctor, and M. Jean Dirlik as honorary chemist.

The "Times earrestly advises the maintenance of the present advantageous position which Great Britiain occupes with regard to Wireless Telegraphy, even at the risk of offending the European Government, until she can discuss the question with the other Governments of the Empire at the approaching Imperial Conference. (Reuter)

it is announced that prince von Bulow will return from Hamburg at the commencement of next week. It is affirmed that the Government had no desire to prevent M. Marconi from attending at the Wireless Telegraphy Conference. M. Marconi was unable to be present owing to his faving to make an important journey to America. (Reuter)
The Earl of Cromer and Sir William E. Garratin have left for Egypt. (Reuter)

The deputation decided yesterday evening to abandon the visit to Russia in view of the misreprenstations of which it had been the object and in order to avoid the possiblity of a misunderstanding. It is understood that one member will proceed to St. Petersburg to present the memorial privately. (Reuter)

div.head:
ANOTHER ASSYR MUTINY.
HEAVY LOSSES ON BOTH SIDES.

div.p: The Benischehr Arabs of the transport Assyr have revolted and killed a hundred Turks and wounded sixty, but have lost two hundred killed. The Turks have been obliged to withdraw and are demanding reinforcements. (Reuter)
The Cabinet has resolved to resist to the fullest extent the law of inforcement of the moduc vivendi with America. (Reuter)

The National Council has been opened. The reprenstatives assembled in the nner court of the palace and were welcomed by the Shah from the window. The members of the diplomatic body were present. The Minister Nizam-el Mulk read a speech expressing the hope that the institution of the Council would have good results for the benefit of the nation. (Reuter)
1647 repatriated Chinese, mostly undersir ables, have arrived here. (Reuter)
The Persian Legation learns that the Shah is seriously ill and that he has nominated his successor. (Havas)

div.head:
THE IRISH OUTRAGES.
THREE FARMERS ARRESTED.

div.p: Three young farmers have been arrested in connection with the Anthenry outrage. (Reuter)
Prominent Jews here have received information that a massacre was started at Tula on Tuesday and was still proceeding yesterday evening. There are no details. (Reuter)
Parliament has been convoked for the 25th instant. (Reuter)
A hundred feet of the Metropolitian Under ground Railway have collapsed. The whole tunnel is threatened. (Reuter)
Middle Park Piate. I. Galvam; 2. Slievegallion; 3. Traquair. (Reuter)

div.head:
PRINCE HOHENLOHE'S DIARY.
A COLOSSAL INDISCRETION.
PRINCE OF WALES AND BISMARK.

div.p: The publication of Prince Hohelohe's diary has produced an indescribable sensation throughout the country. It is regarded as a colossal indiscretion. The details relating to living rulers and statesmen are considered as justifying the Emperor's anger and going to prove that the publication was unauthorised. Writing in 1880, the Prince describes the Emperor as a boyish and inconsiderate young man of whom his mother is afraid and who quarrles with his father. The diary displays the Bismarks in the harehest light.

With reference to the Emperor Frederick, it describes the Empress Frederick, in 1888, weeping because of the disgraceful behaviour of certain people who said that Herbert Bismarck had the imprudence to tell the Prince of Wales that Freerick was incapable of ruling. Whereupon the Prince of Wales said that he would have thrown Herbert out of the room but for the imporatnce which was attached to retaining good relations between Great Britiain and Germany. The Prince of Wales said to Prince Hohenlobe that he was disgusted at the boorishness of the Bismarcks and could not comprehend a policy of irritating France.

The Prince recalls a conversation which he had with the Tear in I-96. The Tsar said that the chief task of his policy was in the Far East. The Japanese had no money and would take years to complete their armaments, and by then the Siberian Railway would be ready and Russia would be prepared for any eventuality. Replying to the Prince's remark that Great Britian was anxious to secure the supremacy in Africa because she was afraid of losing India, the Tsar said: "Who's going to take India! We are not so stupid as to pursue such schemes." (Reuter)

Prince Hohenlobe records a conversation he with the Tsar at Peterhob in 1895. The Tsar referred to his tour in Japan, when Tsarevitch, and the attempt on his life by a fanatic. He said: "In spite of the scar which I bear on my forehead I have much sympathy with the Japanese. Everything I saw in Jpapan greatly impressedme. I was struck by the great orderliness, activity, and intelligence of the population. But my sympathy did not prevent me from acting against the Japanese when they sought to go too far." (Reuter)

The newspaper continue to publish columns of the meoirs of Prince Hohelohe, whose revelations of intriguing and tale-bearing and of the possibility of sanguinary wars being dependent on diplomatist's whims have stupified Germany. It is believed that the publications of the work is due to court intrigue. The German Press condems the re-opening of an old wound. It considers that Bismarck out a better figure than Hohenlohe. (Reuter)
The British Press considers that the disclosure of the rottennes of German bureaucracy will act as tonic to the German people. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
div.p: A number of notables who are interested in the scheme for the formation of a National University met yesterday at the house of Said Bey Zagloul. After considerable dicussion, it was decided to form a committee with Kassim Bey Amin as scretary and Hassan Bey Said as treasurer. Several other members were appointed to the committee, and it was decided to request one of the princes of the Khedividal family to accept the post of president. It was decided in principle that the new university should be opened to all creed and nations, and should be conducted on up to date lines.

"Al Ahram" reports that during the Tantah Show a number of omedhs and notabilites of the establishment of a National Unversity. Forty two of these resolved to write to the orginators of the scheme expressin gtheir willingness to subscribe a considerable sum, and Ahmed Bey Sherif, who was present, immediately made an offer of a hundred feddans of land.

div.head: EGYPTIANS IN SYRIA.
div.p: Our Beyrout Corresponden write: - The staguation that characterizes the summer session was suddenly broken last week, and a temporarily brisk animation made itseld felt in the town. This has been caused by the descrnt from the hills of parents with their chilfren for entrace into the school, and still more by the return of most of the Egyptian summer resorters home. I felt very gratified the other day to hear his Excellency the Vali express his satisfaction at the largeness of the number of Egyptian that have come this summer, and at the fact of his being told that most of them were returning home with far better health and generally well pleased with their journ; all of which augurs wll fro the progressive increase of the number of Egyptian health seekers in the future. Our Egyptian friends should, therefore, have no more any hesitation about coming to their sister land Syria, and, indeed, instead of harbouring any of the old tears regarding difficulties of admission into the country from the part of the lcoal authorities, they should realize that the latter welcome them with a true spirit of enlightened brotherhood, and hospitality.

div.head:
A FATAL FALL.
SAPPER KILLED AT RAS-EL-TIN.
div.p: Sapper Thomas Dixon, R.E., of Ras-el-Tin, was killed early yesterday morning by a fall form the cliff below the British military hospital. According to the evidence produced at the inquest, Dixon, who belonged to "D" block, was sleeping the night in the R.A.M.C. barrack room, and between on and two o'clock yesterday morning, had risen and gone outside the building, and had while at the edge of the cliff, lost his balance and rolled down the slope, falling a perpendicular height of fifteen feet, head foremost, on to the rocks below.

The acciden is easily explained by the nature of the ground. An unprotected oradway shirts the wall of the hospital on the northern side, the rampart having first a steep slope of fifteen feet at an angle of 50, and then a sheer drop to the sandstone rock below of another fifteen feet. Sapper Dixon had reached the edge, and slipping backwards off a wooden border at the top of the slope, had rolled down it; a groover and a gap in the slope showing the direction of his fatal decent.
Dixon was first missed the enxt morning, when Block "D" wired to enquire for him, whereupon a search was made, and the body was found, hunddled up, on the rocks.

An inquest was held at the hospital yesterday afternoon by Mr. Gould, H. B. M's. Consul General, with a jury of three, Messrs, Mun Gavin. Kirby and Whitfield. Private P. J. Lannon, R.A.M.C., stationed at Rus el Tin, stated that he last saw Dixon at 8.30 on Thursday night, when he left decreased in the cateen. Yesterday morning, between ten and half past, when the report of Dixon being missing arrived, Lannon, accompanied by two privvates, both name dWalsh, one being in the Dublin Fusiliers and the other in the R.A.M.C., went out to look for him, going first along the cliff and then on the rocks below, where they found him with his head bent under hi,. They immediately reported the matter to headquarters.

Private Peter WAlsh, R.A.M.C., in his evidence, corroborated all that Lannon had said, adding that between ten and half-ast on Thursday night he saw Dixon sleeping on a spare bed in the R.A.M.C. barrack room, near the door, which was not his regular place of sleeping.

Private John Mathison, 1st BAtatlino, R.D.F., stated that he last saw deceased between one and two o'clock yesterday morning, when Dixion, who was lying next to hi, got up. Mathison spoke to Dixon, who appeared to be quite sober, and said he was going out. Twenty mintues eslapsed but Dixon did not return, and Mathison feel asleep again. At four o'clock, he was roused by the native driver of the transport, and saw that Dixon's bed was empty, except for his cost and cap. However, as he had to transport rations to Mustapha, he had no time then to enquire for Dixion, who was still missing when he returned from Mustapha, at 8 o'clock.

Major Arthur C. Fox, R.A.M.C. o, stationed at Alexandria, stated that he found deceased lying in a semi prine postion , on his right side; his head was doubled up under his body, and resting on a rock; his right arm underneath him, and his left arm thrust out straight. His legs were separated. His body was in a semi nude condition; he had no jacket and his belt was lying at the side of him. From the position of the body and the nature of the injuries death must have been instanteanoues, and from the position of his neck, this must have been broken.
A verdict of Accidental Death was returned.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Before the meeting of the Council of Minsiters at Ras-el-Tin, this morning, which was presided over by the Khedive, his Highness received in audience Sir Vincent Corbett and Mr. P.W. Machell. His Highness will visist the Khedivial Yacht Club, which is holiding a pseical regatta in his honor, and will afterwards return to Montazh.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINSTERS.
div.p: A Council of Minsters was held at Ras-el-Tin Palace this morning, under the presidency of H.H the Khedive, when the folloiwng decrees were approved: -
Decree declaring the alteration works to be carried out at the light railway station at Delingat to be public utility.
Decree authorizing the establishment of an abattoir at Mina-el-Kamh (Sharkeih).
Decree declaring the drain, the agricultural road, the Irrigation engineers offices, and the store, to be constructed at Mellawi, Assoiut, to be works of public stability.
Decree convoking the provinical councol of Beni Soef Moudireh for the 25th inst. to examine the scheme of constructing 34 agricultural roads.
Decree authorising the proposed extension of the Farz and Fourn el Gheraya stations at Gabbari.
Decree authorising the construction of six agricultral roads in the Ghirgeh province.
It was decided to lease to the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company a plot of Government land at Tourah for the imporvement of the Helounan railway service.
The gradual suppression of the tax levied on lands benefitting by the provinces of Beni Souf Fayoum, and Minieh, commecning with the Fayoum in 1907, was decided on.
Approval was given to the establishment of new cemeteries in the provinces of Meuoufieh, Gharibish, Sharkeih, Minieh, and Ghirgeh.

div.head:
EGYPT AND THE BIBLE.
PROF PETRIE ON HIGHER CRITICISM.
div.p: An imporant features of the Church Congress held at Barrow was the discussion on the literary and historical ciriticsm of the Old and New Testaments, and Professor Flinders Petrie's paper dealing with the Bible and the evidence of the inscriptions.

Professors Petrie began wit the latest period, and went back to the ages which were more remotes and obsecure. The curious settlement of the Jews in Egypt in consequences of the persecution of Antiochus Epiphanes, and the building of a temple there by the high priest Oniass IV., had long been a matter of historical debate. This year the site of the town had been found, at Tell el Yehodiyeh , 20 miles north of Cairo; and the foudnation of the temple there showed that it was about half the size of Soloman's Temple, a span for each cubit of the older dimesnison. This was probably the site of the temple of Zerubbabel, from which it was copied. In every respect the accounts given by Josephus were in accord with remains, and his apparent discrepancies were now explained. The beginning of this Jewish occupation of the east of the Delta was seen in the flight into Egypt from Nebuchadnezzar, when all the remant of Judah, the captains of the forces, and the Royal family went to live at Taphaes, now Feenneh. about 30 miles south of Port Said. There might been seen "Pharaoh's house," which Jeremish mentioned, and the pavement which was before the entry where he buried the stores, prophesying that Nebuchadenzzar would pitch pavilion upon it Coming to the period of the Kings of Judah, the early date of Turhaka's campaing (701 B.C.) had long been an hisotrical difficulty. But we now know that he was acting in the Delta, probably as Regent of the Ethipian King, for nine years before his own sole reign in 693 B.C. Hence it was natural that while Vicerory he might be called "King" by the Jews, to whom he was the sole representative of the Ethiopian kingdom. A similar difficulty about So, or Sua, King of Egypt, was similarly removed. Of the well-kown Egyptian account of the Judean campaing of Shisak it would seem needless to say anything more; the riot of negation which had tried to emend the name of Shishak into an entirely difficuerent form in order to disconnect it from the campaign of Sheshank, only showed how rabidly unhistorical so-called ciriticism might become. The anonymous Pharaoh, whose daughter was married to Solomon, could not be identified; but the dates would suggest that he was the last - or last but one- of the 21st dynasty of Tanis. These kings had little or no political powr, and securing a retreat into Palestine would be great advantage for them inc ase of trouble with the rivial dynasty at Thebes. In understanding the dark period of the Judges the one cardinal fact was that there was no trace of Egyptian conquest or intrusion into Palestine in the book of Judges. This bound us to place the entry into Cansan after long series of Egyptian conquests and raids, which extended 1590 to 1186 B.C., the 16th year of Ramessu III. ; or perhaps not later than his eighth year, 1194 B.C. Taking the entry in Canaan as after, about 1190 B.C., the exodus must habe been after 1230 B.C. How, then, were we to understand the records of the Judges. It would be found that no judge was stated to have ruled over more than one of the three great divisions - the north, the east of Jordon, and the west - and no head of Saul. On adding the periods stated for the history of each division, we find 118 years for the north, 122 years for the east, and 121 years for the west, practically idential times. It seemed, then, that there wer in the book of Judges the records of the three several divisions of the land, taken in irregular rotation. From the beginning of the reign of Rashoboam in 937 B.C, we have Soloman 977, David 1017, and Saul beginning about 1030 B.C. This placed the beginning of judge hips about 1150 B.C., and left 25 years (with a margin of ten years more or less) for the slow conquest of Caan. The number of generations in two priestly genealogies agreed also to this shorters reckoning. We must conclude, then, that the book of Judges was a triple record in contemporaneous sections. Before this age was the great inscripiton of Merenptah, stating that "the people of Israel is laid waste, their crops are not, " in the course of a war in Palestine about 1230 B.C. This period to Israelites having remained in Palestine, or returned there before the general Exodus; and in any case it proved that a "peopleof Israel" were known as early as 1230 B.C. Another result in Sinani had been finding a group of inscriptions in a script which was neigther Egyptian nort Babylonina, but which was not akin to Phoenician. The external evidence pointed to these having been out by native Semitic worken, at about rhee centuries before the Exodus. That the Semitic peoples should have had a share in the collections of sings, which were commonly used around the mediterranean thousands of years before this time, was only to be expected; but it was satisfactory to have some examples of such writing before the Phoenician of the tength century, B.C. A third results form Sinai was the view of Semitic worship there, including burnt offerings on the high place, incense altars, an elaborate system of ablutions inside the temple, and dreaming chambers with Bethel-stones. All of these elements of the Jewish system were thus the common heritage of Semites before the Mossaic reforamtion. Lastly, the civilization and history of the shepherd kings or Hyjsos had been partly brought to light from recent work at Tell el Yehudiyeh. The general results was that these people were pastoral Semites.

skin to the moern Bedawy, who probably drifited down the back of Syria and occupied Egypt; they were warriors and trusted to archery and earthworks for their defence. we could hardly help seeing that Abraham, with his 318 men, was on of the "desert princes" of this migratrion coming down the same line into Egypt at the close of that period. Everything that we could trace about the shepard kings exactly fitted to the type of civilisation that we saw in Abraham, Ishmael, Issac, and Eseu. The genearl result of recent work on the Egyptian side was to enforce the strict historical value of the records of the kingly period, to point to the documentary baiss of the acacount of the Exodus, which was probably re-arranged and enriched by each geneartion of the tribal record keepers and to illustrate the narratives of the great national epic of Genesis.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: M. Philon, Greek Consul General at Constantinople, has been definitely appointed Consul-General at Cairo.
M. Nettement, acting French Consul, left Alexandria yesterday for France by the Messageries S.S. Portugal.
Mr. Dupuis, Inspector General of Irrigation in the Sudan, has returned from leave.
We are glad to hear that Fabricius Pasha is now covalescent.

We regret to announce the death of Mr. Bucher Durrer, which occurred a few days ago. The deceased gentlemen was one of the largest hotel proprietors of the world. He was well known both in Switzerland and Northern Italy, where he owned numerous hotels. The new Semiramis at Cairo was one of the deceased gentleman's ventures, and he was also interested in the Excelsior Hotel, now building near the Savoy, Cairo.

div.head:
ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO.
THE BANDMANN VISIT.
div.p: Our readers will no doubt be glad to hear some details concering our visitors of the Bandmann Opera Company, whom many heard and all heard of last year, and who have come back to give a dozen operattas at CAiro on their way home from the Far East.

Many of the same artists and artistes whom we had pelasures in hearing in the spring of 1905 are included in the company. Miss Georgie Corlass is still the leading lady, and Mr. Herry, who visted Cairo a few years ago, is the leading comedian. Mr. Fred. A. Ellis is another comedian of merit who has strenghtened the company. Mr. Mark Lester is back again, and an excellent new baritone, Mr. Ernest Attwall has joined the combination. Miss norah Morrah, here in April 1905, Miss Doreen O'Connor, who ability in soubrette parts is well known, and many others make the Company strong thorughout.

The Company since it last performed at Cairo has been all over the East. proceeding from Cairo it visited Bombay, Colombo and CAlcutta, then proceeded to Rangoon and Singapore, Manilla and Hong Kong. Doubling back, it revisited the scenes of its Indian successes, with Singapore and Rangoon and then returing on its tracks reached Shanghai. From Shanghai the Company went up the Yangtse, and for the first time a dramatic company visited Hankow, where the Club became a theatre for the nocen, and all the large BRitish colony turned up. Then came Japan's turn. The Company played at Kobe and Yokohama, meeting with an excellent reception, returned to Manilla and visited Java. The Dutch gave them a splendid reception. Batavia, Surabaya, Samarang and Tokjakata were all delighted by their performance, and the Bandmann Opera Company was the first that crossed the island. Five weeks were spent in Java, where the hispitality and kindness of the Dutch authorities, who allowed the use of excellent theatres at nominal rents, made this interesting departure from the suual route a great success.

A new Bandmann company leaves for India this winter, and as Mr. Bandmann has lessed the Theatre Royal at Calcutta and is a director of the New Theatre at Bombay, his companies should become even better known there in the future.

As for the repertoire of our visitors, we note several items that are new to Cairo. Among them we may mention Lady Madcap, the Catch of the Season, The Spring Chicken, which so annoyed Mr. Stead, Messeagers' The Little Michus, and Sergeant Brue. Moreover we are to have a peautaomime - Mr. Bandmann's verson of Aladdin, with Mr. Cole as "Mrs. Tawankey," the hero's mother and Miss Corlass as "Aladdin," - which made a great hit at Calcutta.

Altogether the dozen performances given at CAiro should meet with success from first to last and be as largely attened as were those at the beginning of April in 1905, when the public regretted that Cairo could not obtain a longer visit from the company.

div.head: EGYPT'S FOREIGN TRADE.
div.p: PREFERENCE FOR CONTINENTAL FIRMS.

That a British Government should ever attempt to assist the British manufacturere in any way is a thing not to be hoped for in the best of circumstances. Such being the case, it is useless to expect the Egyptian Government, which is supposed to be directly under the influence of the BRitish Government, to assist the British manufacturer. We do not expect fair play, and we do not get it. The practical effect of "Anglicising" Egypt up to now has been increase the percentage of the trade done by Continental firms in that country to the detriment of our own. We adhere in Egypt to a system of measuremnets which handicapts our maufacturers at every turn; we bind the British manufacturer down by hard and fast specifications, whil alloing his Continental compeitor any amount of latitude in quoting, and we so arrange these specifications as often to make it almost a foregone conclusion that the contract must go to the Continent. All this is extremely unfair, but it is characteristics of the policy of succesive British Governments in encouraging our foreign competitors.

It is not, however, of this unfairness that we are complaining at present, but of the stypidity which goes with it, and which, if persisted in, must have the most effect upon Egypt. Our Cairo Correspondent tells us of the decision of the Egyptian Government to admit offically Belgian natural cement in specifications for Government work. Now, Belgian natural cement is not cement at all in the proper sense of the word. By this we mean that the cement which is recognized by the engineers of the world as essential for imporatnt work is of an aritical nature, containg certain definitely specified ingredients which have been sceintifcally treated according to hard and fast rules and subjected to severe tests. The only object in all this very necessary care which is habitually taken in specifiying for sement is to reduce to a minimum the terrible risks entailed by using badly mixed or improperly made cement, the defects of which can only be discovered after the stuff has been used and the damage done.

Now, Belgian natural cement is mixed by nature, and the required ingredients may or may not be present. At the best this stuff is absolutely uncertain in quality. Suffice it here to say that all the world over where it has been used it has created for itseld a record of disaster to buldings and loss to users which is absolutely appalling. It would be insult to the understanding of the Egyptian Government to suggest that they are not aware that in the country from which it emanates - Belgium - its use for Government work it absolutely prhibited, as striclty as we prohibit the storing of explosives in the centre of cities. Its inferiority is so throughouly recognizes by those who handle it that the most elaborate means are taken to disguise its identity in foreign countries. These precautions are also dealt with in the aritcle we refer to above. And now this rubbish, which is sold clandestinely elsehwer, with a British label on it to give it a fictitious air of respectability, is admitted openly for use in Egypt. It is placed on a basis of equality with the real and carefully prepared aritlces, and of course, on account of its nature, will underbid it. Such a policy in a country like Egypt, where huge irrigation schemes are the order of the day, and where, consequently, the question of the quality of the cement used, is an unheard of piece of folly. We should like to know on whose advice the Egyptian Government have done this.
("African Engineering.")

div.head: GREEK AND ANGLICAN.
div.p: REUNION OF CHURCHES.

At St. Alban's, Holborn, the Very Rev Archimandrite Teknopoulos, who has been sent to England by the Patriarch of Constantinople in order to promote reunion between the Anglican and Greek Churches, has been explaining the similiarity between the scramental theory of the Prayer Book as understood by hum and that of his own Church. Perhap the most intersting feature of the meeting was Prebendary Ingram's statement that he hoped during the coming autumn to celebrate the Eucharists in "the Chapel of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre" at Jerusalem, which was to be placed at the disposal of the Anglican Church by the authorities of the Church. This development certainly deserves the attention of ecclesistical students.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain P.R. Wood, Royal Irish Fusiliers, who was recently employed with the Khedive's Army, has been promoted major in his regiment.
On arrival home from Kartoum, Major H. M. Finch, Royal Berks. Regiment, will take over the command of the Depot companies at Reading instead of joining the 1st Battalion at Dublin.
The 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, the 1st Battalion of which is at Alexandria, has moved from Buttevant to Fermony on change of station.
The transport Plassey left Soutampton yesterday with the 2nd Battalion Dosetashire Regiment, and artillery and infantry drafts on board for Bombay. The liner is due at Port Said about the 14th inst.

The 1st Battalin Dorseshire Regiment - the old 39th of Plassey glory, and whose proud mottom is "Primus in India" (first in India) - is due to embark at Bombay on the S.S. Rewa about the 17th November for home. The battalino has been aborad since 1888 when it for England to Malta. It remained in Malta till the following year when it proceeded to Egypt, its sojourn in the Land of the Pharaohs occupying till 1893. In the latter year it moved to India, and has served in the "The Shiny" since, including a turn on the North West Frontier 1897 by which it gained "Tirah" for the green regimental colours. Since its arrival it served in the Punjab, chieftly, and for the last couple of years was stationed at Fergozpore. It may be interest to ass that we well known regimental motto is derived from the fact that the old 39th Regiment of Foot was the first King's regiment as distinguished from the John Company regiments, to arrive in India from Englanf. This it did in 1754, and the following year it fought heroically at Plassey, and other of Clive's great vicotires. The motto first appeearred on a drum major's staff presented to the regiment by the Nabob of Arcot in commemoration of the vicotry over Surajan Dowlah. the dorests on arrival home will take over quarters at Gosport.

The Army Council has decided to allow the issue of serive rifles to mlitai men during the non-training period, with the view of increasing their musketry efficiency by voluntary pratice. The rifles will be issued to the men at the range, and returned after cleaning at the same place, and placed in the regimental armoury. no expenses will be allowed the men, nor will the voluntary practice relieve them from carrying out the usual annual course of musketry.

The present system of promotin to the rank of major-general, though well enough in theory has not given the best results in practice, as an officer's seniority generally depends on the fate on which a vacancy, for which he is specially qualified, occurs. In order to avoid what is a distinct hardship to many, it is suggested that such vacanies should be filled from a permanent establishment of major genearls, and the latter be supplied from a list of the senior selected colonels. The whole system of promotin to general rank is being looked into, it is understood, with a a view to modifying it so as to give the best results.
The battleship Formidable has been recommissioned at Portmouth for another two year's commission on the Mediterranean station.

div.head: A CASE OF INTEREST TO WOMEN.
div.p: 15, Milier Street,
Coatbridge, Scotland.

It is many years ago now since I was first taken with kidney trouble. It began with a dull, grinding pain in the small of my back, but after a while there were sharp, sudden pangs of pain, which nearly brought me down, and these were followed by other symptoms of kidney trouble, eespecially gravel, and great pain in passing water.

During pregnancy, the pains were much harder to bear, and just before the birth of my last chlid there was complete stoppage, which alarmed me very much. My limbs swelled up, and my eyesight was affected. I used to get such pains in the head that I hardly knew what to do with myself.

Doctors and medicine alike failed to give me any relief, but at last I have found help in Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. They have been a real blessing to me, and I will always say so; nothing has every given me such ease. Doan's Pills have strengthened my back, and have made me feel better in many ways. Indeed, I can truthfully say that by their occasional use I keep in better health than I was for years before.
(Signed) Susan Foster,

Some months later, Mrs. Foster said: "I was grateful for the good Doan's Pills did me when I told you about it some months ago, but how much more grateful I feel now that I can tell you it is a lasting cure. There has been no return of my serious kidney and bladder disorders since Kidney Pills relieved me.
"It is my wish that you make this widely known, so that others suffering as I used to, may know how to get well."

Such distressing symptoms as irregular action of the hear, violent, thumping beats, poor circulation of the blood, cold hands and feet, strained breathing, fainitng fits, and dizzy spells, are generally to be traced to the kidneys; seldom is there anything the matter with the heart itself, troubles also will be cured. If, however these disroders are neglected, dropiscal symptoms, such as puffy eyes, and swollen ankles and limbs, will appear, and the body will gradually fill with water.
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T per box.

div.head: NOTICE.
SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: DISPOSAL OF BULDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Buldings Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Building erected by Leasees will NOT be regarded as a ground fro Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lease will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a futher period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculted on the value the site would be bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leashold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issed by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours:
Khartoum: *Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: *Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T)
Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara: Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative.
London: *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institue.
Suez: Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a captial T.
Futher information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documetns on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
div.p: England and Persia.

Russia and this country can now afford to apporach the Persian problem in a more transquil mood than might have been possible a few years ago. The protection of our tarde - which has been seriously prejudiced by the now tariff that Russia imposed upon Persia in 1901 - and the defence of our Indian borders have a course been for many years the cardinal points in our Pesrian policy. They are the cardinal points we must assume, though the menance to our frontier has ceased to be acute for the present. There is practically but one way, short of the hazard of war, in which the great strategical position that we have built upupon our North West Frontier could be seriously endangered. It might be turned by a Russian advance into the Persian province of Seistan, which forms perhaps the only pratical ease for such an operation, and the sourthwards through Persian Baluchi-tan to the Indian Ocean. What we have to do, therefore, is to guard those regions from passing under the Russian control by that process of peaceful penetration in which the Russians have shown themselves to be adepts.
("Times.")
Sowing the Wind.

The only calculation that appears to underlie both the action and the inaction of the Russian Government would seem to be that anarchy may be allowed to go on checked only by the Government;s own Anarchists, "The Union of Russian Men" - until people are tired of it, and are willing to see the autocracy wide thorugh blood to something like its old position. This notion is sinister enough, and yet it might succeed if the economic and social situation were not so desperate. People will not starve, especially whou they are told day by day that food and land be had for the taking. Unfortunately, the weakness of both parties to the great strife in Russia prolongs the period of anarchy, in which devoted and capable men perish, habits of orderely and peaceful life are forgotten, and bad characters come to the top and exact their price. It is a pity that there is no sign at this stage of the Revolution even of a Russian Mirabeau.
("Daily News.")
Russia's Financial Condition.

If the "Temps" has taken proper care to protect itself from being unconsciously made use of for speculative purpose, it would be impossible to exaggerate the importance of the statement it attributes to Mr. Kokovatsoff the Russian Minister of Fiance. This high functionary is represented as having solemnly warned Mr. Stolypin, the Prime Minister, that unless stringent measures are immediately adopted to dimins expenditure, the Russian Empire will be sailing stright towards bankruptcy, and that not far off, either. A Budget deficit of fifteen and a half millions sterling has already come into sight, mainly through the constant increase of outlay on the land forces. Why there should be any commanding occasion for that augmentation of the drain Mr. Kokovatsoff does not venture to conjecture; he confines himself to disclosing the fact. It may be pretty safely surmised, from this reticence, that the persons implicated in the situation are of too exalted position to be brought before the tribual of public opinion. But brishinz all that aside, the European financial world has every cause for serious alarm in the outlook.
("Globe")
The Absence of a Leader.

The Russian revolutionary movement appears to have collapseed into anarchy and the Government's promised reforms to have merged themselves into ineffectual repression. Even those observers who have most faith in the Russian people, and who are most capable of understanding them, seem to see no issue out of the present distressing consitions except through the revival of the autocratic system. This has from the beginning been seen to be one of the possible endings of the movement, and by no means the least likely one. No leader of the people has come to the front, and it seemed all along probable that without a leader able to combine the partieis of reofrm the popular feeling would waste itself in fruitless and destructive outburts. A reovlutionary by the incapacity of its organisers and by the absense of leaders culminate in the reaction and in the revivial of depostism. But unless depostism finds means of making itself efficient it can but produce a fresh revolutionary movement, a fiercer counter-reaction.
("Morning Post.")
The Fight against Socialism.

The great struggle between liberty and Socialism is bound to come upon all people. At one time it seemed that England would to the country which would last be called upon to make the fateful choice. It was with an indulgent and a detached curiosity that we watched in other lands the advance of subversive doctrines, and flattered ourselves that we were protected by our national common sense, as our shores are protected by the sea from the approach of the foreign peril. Events have moved more rapidly here than in France or in Germany, and it may be that, as we have hitberto led the van of human progress, so we are destined to repel the coming assault on freedom and to destroy the anti-social force which is delusively advertised as Socalism.
("Standard.")
A Radical Protest.

The Labour Party has gone to work at the wrong end and by the wrong methods. Had it wished to anunex the whole trade union world it should have gone slowly, have contented itself for the time with propaganda, and have carefully refrained from forcing a decision till it could command something like unaminity. People will not be coerced into joing a party, and the miniority who oppose effiation will deeply its being imposed on them unless by an overwhelming majority. Like other men bent on party advantage to the exclusion of more solid interests, the Labour group think more of their immediate victory in securing the adhesion of a great society than of the lasting effect of their action on the prosperity of the movement.
("Tribune.")
The Morocco Convention.

The Corps Diplomatique acceredied at Tangier has not failed to recognize the importance of not permitting the Art of Algocirz already signed by the Sultan to remain a dead letter, although so far only three Powers have been able to ratify it. Thus recently, at one of those sittings of which they hold several a month they unamously adopted the folloing resolution: - "Although the ratifisication of the Acre Final of Alegericras has not yet been effected by all the Powers, the Corps Diplomatique are in agreement in declaring that all their members in their relations with the Maghzen must adhere to the principles laid down by the Conference. More particularly in matter concerning public works and concessions no deviation shall be made from the rule of adjudication which is inteeded to maintain equality for all in the whole economic sphere."
("Temps.")

div.head: THE TURKISH SUCCESION.
YILDIZ KIOSK INTRIGUES.
div.p: PRINCE MEDJID.

At a moment when the Yidlidiz "camarilla" and the Sultan himself are secreatly engaged in contriving the disappearance of the princes of the Imperial family, and are bsuily discrediting those of them that have any claims upon the sympathy of Europe, to the end that the realisation of the coup d'etat in favour of Prince Burhaneddin may be rendered more certain, it will not (says the "Manchester Guardian's" Constantinople correspondent be without interest to write a few words concerning a prince who, next to Rashad and Yonsouf izzeddin, has most incurred the displeasure of Abdul Hamid.

I refer to prince Medjid, the second son og Abdul Azz born on June 27, 1869. This prince, althouhg, he comes sith in the legal ancession, may in fact be considered as coming third in the roder of sucession, for the princes Suliman, Yshieddin, and Salaheddin, who came between yousouf Izzeddin and Medjid, by their tastes, character, and state of health have little dispoition to rule or are absolutely incapable of diong so.

In order to blacken Prince Medjid in the eyes of Europe and of the Turks and yildz "camarilla" are spreading the report that Mejid would prove a dreadful reactionary, violent, fanatical, and pledged body and soul to Germany. This campaign has not been without effect among those who are ignorant of the real opinions and the worth of Medjid Effendi.

As a matter of fact, however, though a strict observer of the dictates of his religion, he is perhaps the most liberal of the Turkish Imperial House. He speaks French as perfectly as his mother tongue, and is also well acquainted with German. He has kept his political attitude obscure but then the rightly regards it as imprudent to evince a partiality for this or that Power before he actually comes to the head of the State. His determiantoin and ideal is that Turkey should win the esteem and confidence of Europe. He is in favour of a constitutional regime, and - a rate quality among Oriental princes - he devotes the leisure that his serious studies allow him to the cultivation of the European fine arts.

He is subject to the unremitting surveillance of the Sultan, who tinkgs that the disappearance or the discreditng before Turkey and Europe of the Princes Rashad, Youssouf Izzeddin, and Medjid would finally gurantee the success of his contemplated coup d'etat.

The authority of the report - notwithstanding the offical denials emanating from the Palace - that the Sultan's ailment is not merely incurable but, according to the diagnoisis of Dr. Bergmann himseld, leaves him only a few months to live has thorwn the advisers of Abdul Hamid into a state of panic.

The Yildiz "camarilla" know full well the fate that awaits them if any other than Prince Burhaneddin comes to the throne, and are literally out their minds. Those persons in imeediate attendance on the Sultan who have less courage have made secret prepartions for a flight from Constantinople at the momenet of their master's death; the others who are not disposed to take this course are striving with the courage born of despair , to bring Abdul Hamid to precipitate without delay the comp d'ete in favour of Burhaneddin.

As for the group that is plotting to bring a successful issue the combination that consits of causing the Princes Rashad, Youssouf Izzed din, and Medjid to disappear, it is unfortunately becoming stronger day by day, and - judging by the exceedingly influential and fiercely determined men, all high Palace officials, that have become its leavers - more and more influential.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITIOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsbiel for the opinions expressed by our coresspondents in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.
THE HEALTH OF ASSOUAN.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir, - Will you kindgly allow me a small sapce in your valuable paper in which to contradict absolutely a statement that has appeared recently in some of your contemporarires to the effect that there is at present an pediemic of influenza in this town.

Assouan is quite free from influenza, and that which this correspondent has confounded with influenza is simpoly either a very mild form of dengue fever or a kind of slight fever found in all tropical countries possessing a river which rises and falls as the Nile does. This kind o fever usually lasts from three to five days after which time it passes away without any complications whateve, quite unlike influenza.

Whilst on the subject of the health of Assouan, I should like to draw the attention of the Cairo officials of the Public Health Department ot the urgency of having properly filled in the "birket" situated north-east of Assouan. This birket consists of about five acres of s'agnant and foul-smelling water and is proving an excellent breeding place for mosquitoes. The odours from it poison the air, and, unless the matter is seriously taken up, Assouan will be losing something of its well deserved reputation as health resort.
Apologizing for taking up so much of your space, I beg to remain yours, etc.,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hiu a midi et demie.)

L'atteution reste concentree sur la Cassa di Sonto, la Delta Land, L'Urbaine, le Comptoir et un peu sur l'Agricole et la National Bank. Malheureusement la pulpart des affaires se traitent pour fiu courant et c'est tonjours la petite sepculation qui va de l'avant.
La Cassa atteint 229 ¾ l'ancienue et 226 la nouvelle.
De 3 21/32 la Delta Land s'avance a 3 25/32 acheteurs.
Quant au Comptoir, si l'action ne gagne que 1/32 a 7 1/32 et 6 25/32, en revanche la part de fondateur fait un saut de 2 livres a 47/

En hausse egalement la Behera de 1/8 a 37 l'Anglo-Americau Nile de 5/32 a 5 9/16, I'Urbaine de 1/16 a 6 3/8, la Daira de 1/16 a 16 13/16, les Markets de 6 shellings a 28, la Natinal Bank de 1.16 a 26 13/6, et les Nungovich Hotel de 1/16 a 17 13/16.
Par coutre, la Delta Light reactionne legrerement 11 7/8 a 11 27/32, la Banque d'Athenes de 114 ½ a 143 ¾, les Estates de 1 15/16 a 1 29/32.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a hausse 1/8 a 4 ½ pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglaise a encour gane hier `/8 a 86 ½. L'Unifiee est restee invaries a 104 1.4 de meme que la National Bank a 26 7/8 l'Agricole a 9 ¾, la Daira a 16 7/8 et la Delta Light a 11 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Froncier Egyptian a retrograde de 1 franc a 774. La Banque d'Athenes est demeuree inchanges a 144. L'emprunt russe 1906 a reactionne de 83.20 a 83.10.

Ici, la tendance genearle se maintient ferme. Le compartiment des tires dirigeants a ete, il est vrasi, calme, aveo des transcations tres clairsemees; mais, en revanche, les affaires praquess ont ete nombreuses dans les autres groupes, notamment dans celui des petites valeurs.
Dans l'ensemble , l'orientation semble etre toujours a la hausse, retenue en grande partis par la penurie d'or dont la fin ne saurait se produire avant les premirs jours la semaine prochaine.

La National Bank a ete traitee a 26 ¾-13/6. L'Agricole est restee a 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a molli a 227-228. La Bauque d'Orient a progresse a 132 et le Comptoir Fnancier a a debute a 7 pour atteindre 7 1/6 et revenir en clouture 6 15/16 7. La Banque' Abyssainie est remontee a 5 9/16.

Le Credit Foncier a ete bien tenn a 777. La Diara a progresse a 16 7/8. La part de founteur Immobriliere a passe de 735 a 740. L'action Entreprise and Development a ete remenee a 12 13.16 et le part de fondatuer a 22. Les Improvements ont fait 5 11/16 ¾.

Tres mouvementee, l'action Entreprises Immobilierres et Travaux a tteint 4 ½, ache teurs, our fiuri a 4 7/16 ½; la part de foundateur, tres recherchee, a hausee a 93 pour clouturer a 91. L'action Allotment s'est consolidee a 3 3/8 et la foundateur a 127.
Les Automoblies out eu en beau depart a 6 13/16 pour reactionner a 6 ½; 'a part de foundateur a avance a 12 pour fioir a 11 ¾. Les Jouissances Eaux de Caire se sont alourdies a 262.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, le Nungovich ont ete pousses a 18 pour finir a 17 15/16-18. Les Egyptian ont avance a 1/4 de livre a 6 11/16-3/4. Les Upper Egypt ont ete re cherche a 5 1/8. La part a de fondateur National Hotel a progresse a 62.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont gagne tenue, ont atteint les abords de 3 ¾ por revenir, sur des realisation, a 5/8. Un mouvement sigficatif de hausse s'est egalement dessine sur les New Egyptian, qui ont passe de 29 a 31 h., acheteurs. Les Markets ont avance a 27 sh. 3 et les Salt and Soda a 22 sh. Les Estates sont restes a 1 15/16; leur part de fondatuer a progresse a 12 13/16-7/8.
Nous detachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 3 Octobre, le passage suivant:

Les retraits d;or de la Bauque d'Augleterre ont recommence a reprendre a de grandes proportions. Depuis le dernier bilan (26 Septembre) les sorties ont atteint £10,000 pour l'Egypte et le reste pour l;Amerique et diverses autres destinations. Les besoius des Etate-Unis sont, parait-il, loin d'etre satisfaits. La position des Bauques associees de New York s'est toutefois quelque peu ameliorea. Yourjours est-il que le marche de Londres ne se coit pas encore a l'abri de nouvelles saignees de la part de'Amerique et on criot que la Banque d'Angleterre pourrait bien se voir obligee d'elever le taux officiel de l'escompte a 4 ½ pour cent.
L'assemblee generale ordinarie des actionaires de la Societe des Tramways Electriques du Caire aura lieu au siege social a Bruxrllrd le 17 Octobre courant.
Carnet de l'actionaire

Les actionuaires de l'Egyptian Turst and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo) en liquidation, sont prevenus que les versements des deme et Seme appels de 5 sh. devront etre effectues a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank avant le 30 Octobre courant; faute de quoi ils ne pnrront plus echanger leurs titres contre des actions Building Lands. Depuis hier, les retardataires sont passibles d'un interet de 20% l'an.
Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine au 6 Octovre courant se sont elevees a L.E. 1,786 contre 1,553 et 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E 233.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 ont atteint L.E. 63,095 contre 53.454 en 1905, soit on plus value de L.E. 9,642 pour l'exercise courant.
Le recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 4 Octobre se sont chifrees par L.E. 483 contre 400 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 83.
Les recettes totales de l'exercise en cours ont atteint L.E. 25,815 contre 19,266 en 1905, soit en plus value de L.E. 6,549.

div.head: REVUE COMMERICALE
div.p: Cotons.

San nier la relatie, il serait impossible de contester la tenue exceptionnellement bonne de ontre marche aux contrats pendant toute la semaine qui vient de finir: La fermete a regne en plein, et les reactions que nous avons eues pendant les matinees de lundi et de mardi et qui ont ete immediatement suivies de repireses marquees ne sauraient prouver qu'une chose, c'est que notre place n'a pas fait, pour ainsi dire, le moindre des cas de l'Amerique quand elle nour arrivait avec des 30 a 40 points de baisse, tandis qu'elle a accorde toute l'attention voulue aux clotures qui nous veanient en hausse.

Cette tactique et cette tenacite ont fini par trouver leur recomperse, car, en comparant la cote d'aujourd'hui a celle de Vendredi dernier, nour trouvours qu'a 17 25/32, le novembre a gane toute bonement la bagtelle de 3.4 de tallari. Et ce ne sont n aux avis de deterioration a la recolte, - au contarair, elle ne saurait mieux marhcer - si aux achate de la fiature que nous devons ce resultat, mais unique aux convertures des vendeurs en blanc, qui etaient trop en gages, et qui ont fioi par se laisser influencer par les nouvelles du beors et par les agrisenments de leurs adversaires.

Il est incontestalbe que la position se petrait admirablement a la mar coevre qui asi bien resis, maise, maintenant que le decovert est en grade partie elmine, n'u aurait-il pas lien de craindre une reaction non indifferente. Avec l'american, il est certain que la situation de l'egyptien au piont de vue des prix n'est plus ce qu'elle etait il y a deux on trois semaiens; maise est-cjer en lui meme, sans compter qu'an bout du compte l'americain cette hitaine, et par consequent il nous semble qu'a moins arrivent de dehors, la logique exige que l'on se modre pour passfater une situation qui est bonne en elle meme. La pussen des prix au delta de 17 tallaris a arrete la conesommation et si par hassard les avis de degats a la recolte americaine par les gelees ne vernaient pas e tre confirmes, nouse pourrions bien voir l'abstention de la filature, meme monentanee, avec des arriaves de plus copieuz, ous valoir un mauvaise tour. Les engagments de l'exportation sont grands et le demande de sar par pour le disponible sera assez survie et de nature a sider au soutien des prix, maise il ne faudrait pas oublier que d'autre part il ya a cette annee la question de la precipitation avec laquelle la marchandise nous est expediee de l'interiur et equie pourrait produire une agglomeration ou une alluence, aux effets de la quelle il ne saurait etre remedie que par une continutation de la demande de dehors. De la moderation donc, our aturement, nours pourions avoir a njours reprentir par la suite.

En dehors de ce quie precede, il ya susi la qeustion de la recolte: Depuis quelques juers les raports sont des plus favourable et les plus modes es dan leurs estiamtions semblent etre pour les 6 ½ millions de cantar et, quoique cela ne copte pour rein, nous ajoute rons que nous memes nours sommes partisans de ce chifre. Beaucoup parlent meme de 6 ¾ et de 7 millions, mais il pourrait y aboir de l'orgaizaton dans ces evlations. En tous cas la chaleur a fait beaucoup de bein a la troise me cuiellete et si une surpise du chef du rendemnt de la rcolte n'est par tres probable elle n'en reste pasie moins dans le domaine du possible.
Un fait qui nous parlle signifat assi, est que l'interieru ne cease d'offrir du coton d'une facan pressee. Si la recolte n'etait pas bonne est ce qu'il aurait ete anieux de vendre.

L'activite a ete relativenient grande chez nous, mais elle a porte sur l'ancienne recolte et surtout sur les mois elogies qui sont tous mait tenant en report. Ou est donc l'egorgement dont on parliat pur Novembre Del al dont les choses procendt, les haussiers emblelent res pressue de se reporter probablement a cause de imporatnce des arriavages DAnt tous le case, le bon seus indquie de profiter du bon marche des reports actuels.

L'Ameriquie continue a nour bombarder de depeches de tous les gnres miase le pen de progres fait par les prix depuis que les gelles sont a l'ordre du jour aisserait suposer que les degrat n'ont jas l'imporatnce que d'aucuns les degates n'ont pas leu accorder on que les realisations des hassiers gannt et taenant a emparhcer leurs benefices osnt tellemtn fortes qu'elles entravent pour la moment le mouvenmont asscesional. Auatn a la filature que l'on dit tres preoccupes, elle ne bouge pas encor; elle attend probalbement d'etre mieux fixee. Maise si elle n'schete pas, il y a par contre fixaporatio americaine quie parlat recellement accoutn sur Octobre et bon nobmre de depeches de New York attribuent une partie de la hausse a sees sachete. En somme, Killing frost, decurvert, failtes, etc, etc, tout a ete mis a couevre ete out a contibue au movement haussier maise en difnitive depuis 8 jour nous n'avons pas avance de beacoup.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Adminsitration des Chemis de Fer et des Telegraphes de l'Etat a l;honneur de portere a la connaissance de Public qu'a partir du 15 Octobre prochain des Bureaux Telegraph ques seront ouverts opur l'echange des telegramms en laugues europennes et arabe sux Stations de Mohtamadieh, Mit Sudan et Ebiar relevant de l'Egyptian Delta Light Railways.
L'horaire de ces bureaux cera:
de 7 h. 30 a.m. a 1 h. p.m.
et de 3 h. p.m. a 7 h. 30 p.m.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemis de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le public qu'elle dipose d'un poste vacant au Bureau Central des Telegraphes aux appointements de L.E. 7 (sept livres egyptiennes) par mois.
Les demandes d'emploi seront reciesju qu'au 15 octobre courant un concours aura lieu et le meileur candidat sera choisi.
Les candidate doivent remplir les condittions suivantes: -
(1) Etre en possession du certificant d'estudes secondaires.
(2) Ils diovent fournir un certificat de bonne vie et moeurs redige sur papier timbre.
(3) Ils doivent egalemtn joindre a leur demande leur certificat de naissance.
La preference sera donne a celiu des candidate qui const: l'anglais et le francais et sait escrire a la machine.
Le candidat choist devra subir un examen medical par un medecin de l'Administrtaion.
Les demandes d'emploi doivent etre adressecs a M. Inspecteur General des Telegraphes de l'Etate au Caire.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: L'evenemnt tant redoute s'est enfin realise: le taux d'escompte libre en augleterre vient d'etre porte de 4 3/8 a 4 3.4 % et celui del la Banque d'Angleterre de 4 a 5 % Cette emasure deveanit urgent a la suite de la dimution rapide de la propotion des reserves avec les engagments, proption des reserves avec les engagements, proptions qui est encore tombee de 38 1/2 a 35 1/2%. Le Conslide perd 1/8 a 86 ½. A Berlin le taux d'escompte fait un saut encore plus considerable de 4 ½ a 6%. Ces taux prhibits etablish pour sauver la situtation mettent a neat les affiramtion rasurantes des optimsites. IL y a dono une vertiable penurie montaire. La Banque de France est seule a maintenir son taux a 3% mais puet etre seta t elle obligee, elle aussi, de suirvre le mouvement general, pour ne pas liaser diaparallere son encaisese. Quoiqu'il soit, la rente francaise perd 18 point a 95.87 en depit de tous le efforts tentes pour souteuir les cours.

Si la situation fanciere mondiale est loin d'etre satifiasante la situation polituqe ne l'est guere davante. Il est vrai qu'il y a deuz facons d'envisager les cohses et la ou l'un trouve des raisions de craindre l'autre voit des raision d'esperer. Nou n'entreons donc dans le detail des complications politiques que pour efflieuere celle qui nous interesse le plus, a savoir la question d'Egypte: des personnes voienet beaucoup trop au tragique les tendances separatistes des pariotes eguptien; c'est qu'elles prenent au serieux toutes les vaines declamations de quelque meneurs. Au fond il n'y a rien a redonte, du moins pour le moment. Ici on ne se fait pas d'ilusion a ce sujet titre, acucn comprte de evoltions purement ora oires.

Sur le terrain finacier, on se troube movementent geue par le disette du numariare. Les recente arriabes d'or et cue que lion attent encore sufront a piene a statifare les besoins exstants. Le coton se maintenat en hausee, les ventes continuent dant touet l'Egyptite et il faut payre d'omporatns acomptes. De plus, la recolte s'avance et il va faloir en lever et solder le coton. Sans dconte cet argent restera en cirulation dans les pays et u crera sou peu une abounda ce de pcaitaux consdierable, mais en attendant l'argent fait deafut et les banques opposent touhour les memees difficultes pour les avances sur titres.

Est ce a fire que sur palce il n'y ait pas de capitalizste ayant des sommes dipsonbles. Il y en a et beau coup maise les prix actules ne les tentatu pas. Il suffit de jeter un coup d'ceil sur la cote pour boir que les valuesr qui ont profite dernierement d;une plus value ne sont en greneal ni des valuers diregeantues, ni des titre de tout repos, ce qui proive que les achates proveinnent de la patite sepculation. Or celle ci n'a pas l'habitaude de payer intergralement ser acuiqitoins et comme on anvanve dificilment en ce momen cil, il en reulte que le pluarpart en ce moment ci, il en resulte que la plupart des sachts onspur fin. Cette mainere de voir est d;ailurs confermme par les informations que nous avons pu resuliler a ce sujet. Que va til se produire en liquidaiton si les acque eraur impreuetns n'ont pas realise dicilf la Seln toute apprance une baisese olus oui moins sensible qui sura pour resultat d'attirere enfin les acheteru sierx et common sans doute a cette date les fificultes omntaires se seront attenues aussi beine sur le marhce mondial qu'en Egypt, la periode de repiser sura tons les chanes de s'ourivir de une facon defintive.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--

div.head: Supplement Commerical et Financier, De "L'Egyptian Gazette"
div.p: Le Supplement Commerical et Fiancier de l"Egyptian Gazette" parlz charque Samedi a medidi, de facon a puvoir etre expedie par le parquebot autrichen, Il coutient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs; les denieres statsitqiues justqua la veile de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctations de la place et les copies des depches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Assocaition, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
